newsitem.title: GERMANY: Take back citizens or face cuts, Bonn tells Africa.
newsitem.headline: Take back citizens or face cuts, Bonn tells Africa.

text.p: Foreign Minister Klaus Kinkel said on Saturday Germany was no longer prepared to tolerate African countries refusing to take back rejected asylum-seekers, hinting they could be penalised when it came to development aid.

"It can no longer be acceptable that some states, especially in Africa, refuse to take back their own citizens who have to leave Germany or to help with establishing their identity," Kinkel said in an article for Cologne's Express newspaper.
Kinkel said these countries were acting against international law, which obliges all states to take in their own citizens when they have to leave another country.
"If these countries do not change their behaviour, this cannot remain without consequences for relations," he said in the article, released ahead of publication on Sunday.
"The blockade stance, against international law, damages overall relations. These are often characterised by development cooperation. The countries in question know this," Kinkel said.
"We will have to combine Germany's political, economic, development and asylum policy interests more strongly," he said.
